column58: encoding & (20 na encoding) retrieval of 12 word-pairs [ encoding blocks: presentation of unrelated word-pairs die mensen moeten herinneren;; (fMRI studie, dus daarom ook control trials, voor het contrast --> control blocks: presentation of successive numbers of two figures (bv 31-23) --> moeten subjects silently repeaten. ] Ieder word-pair is 3x getoond in de zelfde volgorde. -- om lear strategie effecten zoveel mogelijk te beperken hebben mensen de instructie gekregen om zoveel mogelijk te leren door herhaling (herhalen..) verder geen specifieke strategieen, behalve het maken van visual images (om dat dit waarschijnlijk automatisch gebeurd en inhiberen ervan daarom erg moeilijk is & taak zou beinvloeden..) ----- Retrieval 20 min na encoding.. daar steeds 1 woord van het paar getoond en en dan moeten deelnemers in stilte de andere herhalen. zelfde voor controle bloks. 1 cijfer getoond en dan moeten ze andere cijfer herhalen. .. Direct na de 2de run, subject uit scanner en dan moten ze het scond word van de word pairs helrhaling in respons to het eeerste woords --> dan antwoorden wel recorded.

column43: Time-dependent sensitization (TDS) --> is eignelijk SRS, 1 week tussen initeel stres en restress -->  papers harvey, 2003 bekeken waar naar verwezen wordt. Blijkt: "Rats were placed in a perspex restrainer for 2 h with the tail-gate adjusted to keep the rat well contained without impairing circulation to the limbs. Immediately thereafter, the rats were individually placed in 18 cm of ambient water (258C) in a perspex swim tank and allowed to swim for 20 min. Following this, each rat was then immediately exposed to 0.8 ml of 4% halothane vapours in a 5-l sealed plastic container until loss of consciousness, and then removed. -- The rats were then placed in a Tempadair drier before being returned to their cages. The animals were left undisturbed for 7 days. Seven days after the initial stressor, the rats were exposed to a ‘restress’ session, consisting of a 20-min swim in 18 cm of ambient water (25 8C) in a perspex swim tank."

column43: Deployment
column49: combat controls (trauma exposed controls)
column58: Surprise memory test (1 week after encoding [ 160 stimuli: 60 high arousing trauma combat photo's; 60 neutral photos, 40 positive photos ] - recognition memory task [160 original + 80 novel lures [similar scenes as orignial pictures (30trauma, 30 neutral, 20 positive)], all in black-white. PP had to indicate if picture is old or new & how confidence they are (4point scale)
column61: proportie [hits (rememberd correctly + high level of confidence (=3 of 4)) - hit rate all hits/all stimuli at encoding; misses; FA falsely rememberd lures dived by total numer of lures | response bias (criterion) = [z(hit) + z(fa)] /2 --> index of tendency to overrespond or underrespond (hoe liberaal ben je)]
column63: all participants highest hits voor trauma stimuli (compared to neutral) - no diff control vs patient | FA highest for trauma pictures, vooral in patienten!  Geen verschil in FA voor neutral stimuli --> patients less detalied memories, mainly driven door hoge FA rates dan controls --> mogelijk meer gok herinnering zonder veel contextual details. [OOK positive response bias in beide groupen, maar geen groups verschil. F(1,27=1,2,p>0.2) data verder niet in tabel of in artikel]

column63: p.2: California Verbal Learning Test indices, the performance of the PTSD-positive group was worse than that of the other two groups on number of words learned (F=4.82, df=2, 44, p=0.02) and short-delay free recall (F=3.63, df=2, 44, p=0.03). -- Highlighted 17 Jul 2017 | p.2: long-delay recall (F=5.74, df=2, 44, p<0.01 Post hoc analysis indicated that the PTSD-positive subjects recalled fewer list items than did the PTSD-negative and comparison groups -- Highlighted 17 Jul 2017 | p.2: NS: category cues were provided to the subjects, the recall difference declined to a nonsignificant level (F=3.75, df=2, 44, p=0.03). -- Highlighted 17 Jul 2017 | p.2: NO between-groups difference was observed in recognition hits (F=0.63, df=2, 44, p=0.54). -- Highlighted 17 Jul 2017 | p.2: no differences in learning strategy were apparent, as the three groups had similar scores on the semantic and serial clustering indices. -- Highlighted 17 Jul 2017

column43: Stress re-stress paradigm: 1) Stress (SPS):(start at 8:00 on D-2 of experiment): 2h restrained - foreced swim 20min (diameter 18cm, 18cm depth water, 25 graden) - halothane exposure (general anesthetic). |  <undisturbed> | 2) Re-stress: D-8: forced swim (20min).. column58: Y-Maze test after stress & restress tests [ steeds nieuwe cues per test, zodat ze nieuw blijven voor de dieren] - {Y-maze (total 3arms): explore 2 arms for 15min, then 4h later: explore all arms (3) 5min --> number of entries recored [ ter info:  total numer of entries = general exploration attitude; %entries in known vs novel arm (5min) = spatial recognition memory; coping to novel invironment: % of time spent in novel amr/ time spent in all arms & in center [--> decrease in coping behavior = increase in anxiety])

column3: Litz, B. T., Weathers, F. W., Monaco, V., Herman, D. S., Wulfsohn, M., Marx, B., & Keane, T. M.
column14: Cognitive system - Declarative memory & Cognitive controle - Response selection,performance monitoring
column20: modified Stroop procedure (MSP), a standard Stroop procedure, a recognition memory task, and a threat rating task.
column26: attention(stroop), memory, recognition bias?
column28: Recognition memory for woorden in modified stroop test. MemorY? Nu geincludeerd na modified stroop (waar de memory items vandaan komen) nog een gewone stroop ertussen.. En daarna memorie test)
column31: memory van stroop stimuli.. Te simple als memory task?
column32: ook SCL SCR & HR gemeten (baseline & tijdens stroop) | ptsd group, andere as1 issues group en no-as1 problemen groep ; NB in PTSD group wel  comorbidity| recognition memory voor woorden in modified stroop test… (includeren of excluderen?).. Verschillen in soort threat (military specifiek of niet), test de hypothese of interferences is trauma-related of generiek for treat
column43: Deployment (vietnam verterans)
column49: Combat Controles
column53: PTSD module SCID (DSM-III-R) & Mississippi Scale score  107 of hoger
column56: 2 ( 3 in paper: current PTSD, andere as1 (=psychiatric comparrison group), no as1) | As1 control group niet opgenomen
column58: Recognition memory test for words in modified stroop task (waarin 2 levels aanwezig zijn: nml threat-level (high vs. Low) en content (military vs education) | confidence ratings + 'old' vs ' new' responses on 14-point likert scale ('very certane old' to 'very certane new') | Memory operator characteristic (MOC) curves berekend per deelnemer (reflecting Hit rate tov false alarm rate for each word type)
column61: Signal detection analysis; probability of area under the MOC curve (P(A) used as nonparametric measure of memory sensistivity (Hartwick, 1979) (perfect discrimination = 1); P(A) approcimate d-prime, standard parametric method used to assess memory discrimination (when old en new are distributed normal) | [ook memory bias gemeten (nonparametric B) door te kijken bij welke confidence value subject equally disposed to 'old' & 'new" repsonses. response bias scores range from 0 - 14 (low score indicate lax criterion en bigh scores indicate strict criterion).. data nu niet opgenomen
column63: geen verschil tussen hc & ptsd; all subjects, regardless of word-type, demonstrated extremely accurate recognition memory. (taak te makkelijk als memory maat?); threat beter onthouden dan neutral en military content beter dan educational content
column77: Recognition memory sensitivity, or P(A). The repeated measures ANOVA showed a main effect of content (F(1,48) = 28.43, p = .0001) and threat (F(1,48) = 7.60, p = .008). There were no significant interaction contrasts. (geen groep effect dus) As can be seen by the P(A) values shown in Table 5, all subjects, regardless of word-type, demonstrated extremely accurate recognition memory.

column32: p.2608: Each experiment followed the basic paradigm: 3 days of startle acclimation/matching, 1 day of classical fear conditioning, and after a 96-h gap, a fear-potentiated startle test session -- Highlighted 15 Feb 2017 | p.2608:  Following a 5-min acclimation period, five pairings of 3 s of the light CS co-terminating with a 500 ms, 0.6 mA foot shock occurred -- Highlighted 16 Feb 2017
column43: p.2608:  Following a 5-min acclimation period, five pairings of 3 s of the light CS co-terminating with a 500 ms, 0.6 mA foot shock occurred -- Highlighted 16 Feb 2017
column58: (in verschillende experimenten) CUE after a 96-h rest (na fc), the rats were tested for fear-potentiated startle. The testing consisted of 5min of acclimation followed by 70 startle trials with 15 s intervals. The first 10 trials that consisted of 95 dB noise bursts were not used in any analyses. The next 60 trials consisted of 95, 105, or 115 dB noise bursts, with half presented either in the dark or co-terminating with the 3s light CS. & CONTEXT: After 96h, rats were given saline or oxytocin, and 30 min later, instead of testing cue-specific light CS fear-potentiated startle, con- textual fear was examined by presenting only Noise trials.

column58: Probabilistic classification task (20min): 4 stimuli per participant (S1,S2,S3,S4), participants has to classify them in category A or B (S1&S3 horen bij A in 80%vd trials en tot B in 20% vd trials; S2 & S4 horen tot B in 80% van de trials en 20% vd trials bij A); S1 &S2 reward (dus bij goed gain van 25points, bij fout geen feedback) en S3 en S4 punishment (dus bij fout aftrek van 25 punten, bij goed geen feedback); totaal 160 trials, in blocks van 10 trials (8 common strategie 2 uncommon); 80 punishment en 80 reward trials; start totaal 500 punten;

column77: p.3: main effect of Strain, F(1,60) = 26.69, p < 0.01, with WKY rats showing significantly longer PA response scores than Wistar rats. -- Highlighted 3 Nov 2017 | p.3: Rats exposed to the tail shock prior to PA training demonstrated superior PA retention scores compared to rats exposed to the retroactive sequence, and this was disclosed by the significant main effect of Shock Sequence, F(1.60) = 4.04, p < 0.05. -- Highlighted 3 Nov 2017 | p.3: The tail shock controllability treatment produced different PA retention scores, F(2,60) = 4.48, p < 0.02. The post hoc test indicated that this significant effect was due to the longer response latency scores for the IS rats than rats exposed to either the ES or the NS treatments, Tukey HSD test, p < 0.05.  -- Highlighted 3 Nov 2017 | p.3: Post hoc tests disclosed that WKY rats exposed to the IS and ES treatments had significantly higher PA scores than the Wistar rats -- Highlighted 3 Nov 2017

column39: * (weight 175-200g --> lijkt jonger dan 42 days te zijn en ouder dan 21 days.. | aan begin experiment, daarna 7day acclimatiseren (dan SPS))
column41: * (weight 175-200g --> lijkt jonger dan 42 days te zijn en ouder dan 21 days..)

column56: 2 (4 in total paper; invloed van 14day exersice tussen sps en behavioral experiments onderzocht)
column58: Radial Arm Water Maze (RAWM) 14days after SRS: The RAWM consisted of a black circular pool filled with water at 25 °C containing six swim paths in a dimly lit room. Each rat was ran- domly assigned a goal arm which contains a hidden black platform near the end of the arm. The rats were randomly released at an arm different from the goal arm, allowed to swim and locate the platform which is submerged 1 cm under water. The rats were allowed 1 min for each learning trial or memory test | If the rat failed to locate the platform within 1 min, it was manually guided to the platform and scored with 7 errors. Upon reaching the platform, the rat was allowed 15 second rest before the next trial began. | Each rat was subjected to a set of six learning trials (trials # 1–6) followed by a 5 min rest period and then another set of six learning trials (trials # 7–12). | The short-term memory test was conducted 30 min after the end of 12th trial. This was followed by the long-term memory test which was given 24 h later.
column60: ? [12h light, 12h dark cycle; lights on at 0600h]
column61: An error was counted when the rat entered more than halfway into an arm other than the goal arm or if the rat entered more than half of the goal arm but failed to approach the platform. Number of errors ranged from 1 to 7, as the rat can only swim into a total of 7 arms within 1 min. [learning; short & long-term24h memory test]
column63: ptsd slechter spatial memory short en long term, meer dan 14day na trauma
column77: ptsd more errors --> less short term spatial memory

column43: mouse defense test battery (exposure to Male long-evans rats): [The test consists of six different phases: 1) Pre-test: Mice were placed into the apparatus for a 3-min familiarization period, in which line crossings and escape attempts were recorded. 2) Rat avoidance test: After this period, a handheld rat was introduced at the opposite end of the apparatus and brought up to the subject. If the mouse fled, avoidance distance was recorded. 3) Chase-flight test: The handheld rat was brought up to the subject. Chase was initiated only when the subject was at a standstill and completed when the subject had traveled a distance of 15 m. During the chase, the number of stops (pause in movement) was recorded. 4) Straight alley: By the closing of two doors (60 cm from each other), the runway was then converted to a straight alley in which the subject was constrained. The rat was introduced in one end of the straight alley. For 30 s, the number of approaches and withdrawals (subject had to move more than 20 cm forward from the closed door, then return to it) was recorded. 5) Forced contact: The experimenter brought the rat up to contact the subject in the straight alley. For each such contact, upright postures and bites by the subjects were noted. 6) Post-test: Immediately after the forced contact test, the rat was removed and the door opened. Line crossings and escape attempts including wall rears, wall climbs, and jump escapes were recorded during a 3-min session. ] + 2 weeks later reexposure to runway (=threat context) zonder rat (=threat) - 3min

column58: 14-15 day after threat (2h after context reexposure): Object recognition task (ORT): p.69: During a first session, mice were allowed to become familiar with the experimental environment for 7 min and the time spent in activity was measured. Twenty-four hours later, mice were again placed in the enclosure in the presence of two identical objects until they reached 15 s of object exploration (acquisition session).  -- Highlighted 02 Aug 2017 | After a 60-min interval, mice were placed again in the enclosure with a previously presented familiar object and a new one for 5 min (retrieval session) = short term memory test
column61: exploration of an object was defined as pointing the nose to the object at a distance of less than 2 cm and/or touching it with the nose. | p.69: e following parameters were analyzed: (a) locomotor activity during habituation session; (b) the time to reach 15 s of exploration of the 2 identical objects in the acquisition session; (c) the time of exploration of each object during retrieval session (=5min); (d) the total time of exploration (sum of both objects exploration times) and (e) the ratio of the time exploring the new object of the total time of exploration -- Highlighted 02 Aug 2017

column1: Samuelson, K. W., Neylan, T. C., Lenoci, M., Metzler, T. J., Cardenas, V., Weiner, M. W., & Marmar, C. R. (2009). Longitudinal effects of PTSD on memory functioning. Journal of the International Neuropsychological Society : JINS, 15(6), 853–861. Journal Article, Research Support, Non-U.S. Gov’t. http://doi.org/10.1017/S1355617709990282
column3: Samuelson, K. W., Neylan, T. C., Lenoci, M., Metzler, T. J., Cardenas, V., Weiner, M. W., & Marmar, C. R.
column14: Cognitive system - Declarative Memory
column20: visual and verbal memory, and working memory
column25: longitudinal effects of ptsd on memory functioning
column28: longitudinaal, 2 meetpunten per subject
column32: longitudinal study (2 meetpunten per deelnemer, over een periode van 2-5 jaar) - zo te zien geen deelnemer geswitched van group tussen meetpunt 1 & 2; The major findings of this study are as follows. First, partici- pants with PTSD showed a significant decline in measures of delayed visual recall and recognition during the 2–5 year in- terval of the study. Second, decline in delayed facial recognition was significantly greater for veterans with PTSD compared to veterans without PTSD. Third, veterans with PTSD did not demonstrate any improvement in PTSD symptom severity over time, and change in PTSD symptomatology was not associated with change in neurocognitive performance. Fourth, there was no effect of age on memory decline, suggesting that longitudinal decline in the PTSD+ group was not attrib- utable to advancing age.

Third, veterans with PTSD did not demonstrate any improvement in PTSD symptom severity over time, and change in PTSD symptomatology was not associated with change in neurocognitive performance. Fourth, there was no effect of age on memory decline, suggesting that longitudinal decline in the PTSD+ group was not attrib- utable to advancing age.

column61: Moving to the other chamber while the signal light on was counted as avoidance, and moving to the other chamber upon receiving foot-shock was counted as escape. p.38: error; not moving to the other chamber and receiving the entire 15-s foot-shock | unnecessary cross; moving through the gate after cessation of foot-shock prior to next signal light ; During a 5-min adaptation period prior to the task, the number of movings through the gate was counted as cross in adaptation (cross in adapt)| p.38: rat moved to the other chamber, the foot-shock and signal light were terminated immediately.

column58: proprietary version of the Memory for Intentions Test: 8 prospective memory(PM) tasks over 30 min that are balanced by type of cue (i.e., time-based vs. event-based), mode of response (i.e., physical vs. verbal), and delay (i.e., 2 min vs. 15 min). -- Highlighted 30 Aug 2017. ondertussen moesten deelnemers een search word puzzel maken. (0-2 punten per trial, waarvan 1 punt voor antwoorden 1 punt voor het juiste moment op de juiste cue.) - Iedere trial contributes to three of the MIST's six subscales (range = 0-8), summed to create summary score (0-48). [Daarnaast ook een 8-item, three-choice recognition trial at the end of each PM task --- data op andere regel]
column61: Summary score, Time-based trials & Event-based trials (mediaan, IQR, Mean & SD) & [als secundair separate error type totals for the timebased and event-based scales (range 0-4)] p.726: addition, we generated separate error type totals for the time-based and event-based scales (range, 0–4). Consistent with prior studies (Woods et al., 2008), errors were coded as PM failure (i.e., no response omission errors), loss of time (i.e., executing an intention ≥15% target time), task substitution (e.g., responding verbally instead of with an action or vice versa), or loss of content (i.e., awareness that a response is required but failure to recall the content) errors. -- Highlighted 31 Aug 2017
column63: PTSD group worse on MIST sum score, time-based trials (bv. Doe over 15 min dat ). Maar niet op event-based trials- (=als ik je dit geef, moet jij dat doen). PTSD group ook meer time-based PM failure errors (i.e. Omissions) dan controles. Time-based -> hogere cog. load dan event-based trials [Theoretical models of PM have proposed that time-based PM is more heavily dependent on self-generated monitoring and retrieval processes associated with cognitive control (McDaniel & Einstein, 2000), which is associated with the integrity of prefrontal circuitry and associated executive functions (Einstein, McDaniel, Richardson, Guynn, & Cunfer, 1995) implicated in PTSD (Aupperle, Melrose, et al., 2012).] & [ event-based PM typically relies on externally prompted, less effortful, and more automatic retrieval (Einstein et al., 1995). In the context of these models, it may be that individuals with PTSD have greater difficulty accurately completing future intentions when tasks require greater internally guided allocation of cognitive resources.]

column25: wel controle voor ptsd, niet alleen ptsd sample
column28: No PTSD Group/Model | geen only ptsd group (maar combi van psychopathologieen, namelijk MDD(14,1%), PTSD (31,5%) & mTBI (32,1%)), wel een HC group --> dus geen cog. Data voor ptsd only presented
column32: geen verschil tussen ACT scores van individuals with en without ptsd diagnose (means not reported, t=-1,85,NS,d=0,30); is act echt cognitief? ACT = auditory Consonant Trigram's - measure immediate memory in absence of rehearsal (ACT, 3 medeklinkers soms gevolgd by number (alleen in in 0s trials). deelnemer moet dan terugtellen by threes van het gegeven nummer en een interval van 0,9,18,36s verbal de driemedeklinkers rapporteren | in totaal 20trials --> sum score voor ieder einterval, higher score = better performance

column32: p.103: exclusions from this group included lifetime or current bipolar or psychotic disorder (n = 1), selfreported learning disability (n = 6), scored below 45 on Trial 1 of the Test of Memory and Malingering (Hilsabeck, Gordon, Hietpas-Wilson, & Zartman, 2011; Tombaugh, 1997; n = 1) or neurologic diagnoses (n = 0), except for mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI; n = 32). -- Highlighted 06 Sep 2017
column43: Combat & non-combat: Sexual trauma alone or in combination with combat trauma was the most common trauma type (n = 46); participants reported sexual trauma only (n = 17), combat trauma only (n = 10), or combat and sexual trauma (n = 29). Of those reporting sexual trauma, 14 reported both childhood and adult trauma, and 32 reported adult-only trauma. Other traumas included transportation accidents (n = 47), the death of someone close (n = 28), physical assault (n = 45), natural disaster (n = 30), serious accident or injury (n = 19), weapon assault (n = 24), and fire/explosion (n = 26).
column49: healhty controls mixed (non-veterans n=36) & OEF OIF veterans n=17), dus ook exposed controls: [p.104: Trauma breakdown for the control group included combat (n = 10), transportation accidents (n = 34), the death of someone close (n = 17), physical assault (n = 12), natural disaster (n = 17), serious accident or injury (n = 7), weapon assault (n = 6), and fire/explosion (n = 7). -- Highlighted 06 Sep 2017] (dus veel trauma in control group ook, weet echter niet zeker of ALLE control deelnemers een trauma hebben mee gemaakt (waarschijnlijk wel)

column58: California Verbal Learning Test (CVLT-II): A composite mea- sure from a previous PTSD study (Gilbertson et al., 2006) was calculated by averaging the derived z scores from the test man- ual for each of the following: List A Total Recall, List B Recall, Short-Delay Free and Cued Recall, Long-Delay Free and Cued Recall, Across-Trial Recall Consistency, Percent Recency Re- call, Semantic Clustering, Recognition Hits, and percent change in recall between Short-Delay Free Recall and Trial 5 Recall (α = .85). column26: environmental enrichment; locomotor activity & elevated plus maze & openfield test; avoidance/escape shuttle box (leren? Of situational reminder?)
column28: escape/avoidance task
column32: zelfde taak als in swamura et al 2004
column43: inescapable footshock (60x IS (0.8mA, 15s duration); iti 7,5-22,5s random (mean 15s); in shuttle box - deur dicht
column49: 30 min in shuttle box (no shock) - deur dicht
column58: escape/avoidance task - 2 week after IS in zelfde shuttle box (80 escapable foot-shocks for 15s at 0.8mA; gate open en warning signal 5s before shock) [NB dus even sterke shock als tijdens trauma EN in zelfde context (shuttelbox..)] Prior to task 5min habituation period waarin numer of movings through the gate was counted as cross in adaptation (cross in dapt) [maat voor herinneren IS) | Each trial was divided into three segments: a conditioned phase of 5 s, an unconditioned phase with a maximum length of 15 s, and a random ITI of 1577.5 s | The CS and US were terminated immediately after the rat moved to the next compartment
column61: p.121: If the rat moved to the next compartment during CS presentation without US presentation, avoidance was recorded -- Highlighted 6 Nov 2017 | If the animal failed to respond, both CS and US were terminated at the end of the 15 s trial. Movements through the gate after the foot-shock were terminated, and prior to initiation of the next light signal (CS), were recorded as crossings during the ITI (Fig. 3E).
column63: IS more avoidance (ze herinneren) en more crossings during ITI (teken v generalizatie?)
column77: IS more crossings during ITI (teken van generalizatie?)

Journal Article, Research Support, Non-U.S. Gov’t. http://doi.org/10.1016/j.nicl.2014.05.005
column3: Tian, F., Yennu, A., Smith-Osborne, A., Gonzalez-Lima, F., North, C. S., & Liu, H.
column14: Cognitive system - WM
column26: working memory; multichannel functional near infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS); digit forward & backward task) --> encoding; maintenance, retrieval van WORKING MEMORY

column1: Tischler, L., Brand, S. R., Stavitsky, K., Labinsky, E., Newmark, R., Grossman, R., … Yehuda, R. (2006). The relationship between hippocampal volume and declarative memory in a population of combat veterans with and without PTSD. Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences, 1071, 405–409. Journal Article. http://doi.org/10.1196/annals.1364.031
column3: Tischler, L., Brand, S. R., Stavitsky, K., Labinsky, E., Newmark, R., Grossman, R., … Yehuda, R.
column14: Cognitive system - Declarative Memory
column28: wel geschikte studie (qua design, maar er is geen data per group gerapporeerd (M,SD voor ptsd+ of controls), alleen correlatie tussen CAPS & CVLT performance berekend. Bevindingen: in hele sample geen correlatie, PTSD+, but not PTSD−, group, severity of lifetime (worst episode), but not current, PTSD symptoms were negatively correlated with several components of CVLT learning (List A Trial 5: r = −0.509, n = 17, P = 0.037; SDFR: r = −0.519, n=17,P=0.012;SDCR:r=−0.594,n=17,P=0.012;LDFR:r=−0.706, n = 17, P = 0.002; and LDCR: r = −0.752, n = 17, P = 0.001). -- Highlighted 07 Sep 2017 [ trekken de conclusie dat het een risk en geen effect symptomen is (door dat er geen correlatie met current ptsd symtpoms gevonden wordt, maar met lifetime ]
column31: kort en bepert
column32: PTSD group: 11 current, 5 past ptsd | control: never ptsd || participants were excluded if they had psychosis, current substance dependence, an active medical or neurological illness, a history of bypass surgery, or significant head trauma
column43: Deployment
column49: Combat Controles - never ptsd
column58: California Verbal Learning Test (CVLT)
column61: dependent variables: immediate attention (number of words recalled following trial 1), performance on learning trials 1 through 5 (total learning), after a short delay (short-term retention; short-delay free recall [SDFR]) and after a longer delay (delayed recall, long delay free recall [LDFR]), as well as short-delay and long-delay Cued Recall (SDCR, LDCR), and a recognition test, which yields the number of correctly identified target words (recognition hits) | Additional variables included proactive interference (difficulty in subsequent learning as the result of initial learning), retroactive interference (difficulty recalling previously learned information as the result of newly learned information), retention (LDFR– SDFR; short-term retention compared to long-term retention), and response bias (on the basis of the recognition hits).

column3: Toledano, D., & Gisquet-Verrier, P.
column14: Cognitive system - Declarative Memory & Negative Valence - Potential Threat (anxiety)
column28: avoiance of new oder (geen memory) (je zou nog discriminatie index kunnen berekenen) | trauma exposed onderverdeelt in susseptible en resilient group; data uit grafiek afgelezen/ suseptible (=ptsd) group vergeleken met trauma exposed resilient en unexposed controls
column31: nb animals gestes in 2 cohort, daarna groepen samengevoegd
column43: resiliten VS sussectible SPS [2h restrained; 20 forced swim; 15min rest; exposure to room saturated in CO2 till loss of consciousness (ong. 45-50s) + Olfactory (piece of cotton wool soaked in lemon oil (100ul) - during restrained) & auditory (pink noise 20Hz to 20kHz bandwidth; 80dB - present throughout SPS) cues
column49: SPS exposed - resilient
column53: exposed [onderverdeelt in Resilient & Susceptible, based on basal level of anxiety (EPM) en reactivty to novelty (locomotor in Circular corridor) --> rangt per behavioral triant & median split & non-exposed - p.169: Rats were considered to develop PTSD-like symptom when their performance (on avoidance of trauma-associated odor, reactivity to trauma -realated tone, response to acoustic startle & EPM postest) differed more than one standard deviation from the mean level of the CTRL group, in 3 indices with more than a half standard deviation in the EPM post-stress test -- bij 3/4 'symptomen' --> suseptible group
column58: Avoidance of trauma-associated Odor (D36 na SPS): Y-Maze with filter paper soaked in 100ul of either peppermint oil (new oder) or lemon oil (trauma-associated odor for SPS rats & new odor for CTRL rats) placed under the grids of two different arms; 3e arm free of specifc odor [location of ams changed during the 2 days] - 5min free exploration time| & | Reactivity to trauma-associated tone (D43 na SPS): 10min in box, freezing recored 70s before first tone; 2 seires of 20s tone separated by a two-minute interval: 1 session New tone (75dB, 500Hz, 2e session trauma tone (80dB pink noise); each tone delivered 3 times met variable time interval (45-80s)
column61: Odor: time spend (S) in each section of Y-Maze [entry=80% of rat's full body enterd the open or closed arm; exit=70% outside of the area - time in trauma-associated & new odor area's is index of avoidance | Tone: % freezing behaviour during tone, post-tone
column63: Resilient trauma exposed rats onthouden trauma ODOR cue, suseptible rats niet..; SPS-S rats freeze more to new & trauma tone then control EN SPS-R..(--> suggest some generalization) | SPS-R maken geen onderscheidt (geen memory hiervoor of geen angst?)
column77: SPS-S less time in new odor arm then SPS-R & control ; geen verschil tussen Control en SPS-R
column78: CTRL vs SPS-S:  (F(1, 19) = 5.15, p = .033 ) & SPS-R vs SPS-S: F(1, 13) = 5.26, p = .037 | CONTROL-SPS-R: (New odor arm: F(1, 22) = 1.01, ns;)

column26: inhibition task: stop-signal anticipation task (SSAT); response inhibition  --> moving bar stoppen (go trial) of response inhiberen als bar zelf stopt (stop signal).. De contextual cues zijn de kleur van de bar's (die laten de kans zien dat een trial een stop trial is) [subjects typicaly slow down their responses, as they anticipate that the bar will stop. slowing = contextual cue processing

column58: Continuous Visual Memory Test (CVMT): continous recognition memory during initial learning & multiple-choice recognition after 30min delay & perceptual matching task consisting of multiple choice selection of the target item from a seven-item array
column61: p.128: Variables of primary interest for the CVMT included total correct during the learning phase and total correct after the 30-min delay. Qualitative measures included false positives during the learning phase. The perceptual matching task was administered to exclude the possibility of influence of primary perceptual deficits on m em ory perform ance. -- Highlighted 07 Sep 2017

column58: Rey Auditory Verbal-Learning Test (AVLT): 5 learning trials list A, interference trial of new list (B), short delay recall of list A en long-delay recall 30 min later, & yes-no recognition test (direct na delay memory) met targets(A), list (B) woorden, en niet eerder geziene woorden (nonstudied distractor)
column61: p.128: To replicate previous research, variables of primary interest for the AVLT pertained to proficiency of List A recall and included the sum of correctly recalled words List A, Trials 1—5; total correct List A, short-delay recall; and total correct List A, long-delay recall. In addition, qualitative indexes included proactive interference and retroactive interference ratios, expressed as the follow ing: L ist B recall/Trial 5, List A recall and short-delay. List A recall/Trial 5, L ist A recall, respectively; a savings ratio, expressed as long-delay recall/short-delay recall; intrusions and perseverations, List A, Trials 1-5 and delayed-recall conditions; and long-delay recognition hits and m isses.  -- Highlighted 07 Sep 2017
column63: PTSD slechter in verbal learning & free recall (short & delay),  [ptsd slechter memory quality: ptsd more intrusions; en more false positives bij recogntion] &&--> retroactive interferences ratio hoger in controls
column77: control better then ptsd in long delay verbal recall

column61: p.128: To replicate previous research, variables of primary interest for the AVLT pertained to proficiency of List A recall and included the sum of correctly recalled words List A, Trials 1—5; total correct List A, short-delay recall; and total correct List A, long-delay recall. In addition, qualitative indexes included proactive interference and retroactive interference ratios, expressed as the follow ing: L ist B recall/Trial 5, List A recall and short-delay. List A recall/Trial 5, L ist A recall, respectively; a savings ratio, expressed as long-delay recall/short-delay recall; intrusions and perseverations, List A, Trials 1-5 and delayed-recall conditions; and long-delay recognition hits and m isses.  -- Highlighted 07 Sep 2017

column58: avoidance/escape test in shuttle box - the gate was always kept open during the avoidance/escape task session that was performed 2 weeks after the initial IS or sham IS treatment. |warning signal light was provided 5 s prior to each IS. (footshock = 0.8mA, max 15s) | Additionally, a warning signal light was provided 5 s prior to each IS. During a 5-min adaptation period before the task, the number of movements through the gate was counted as a cross in adaptation (cross in adapt), and movement within the chamber was counted as locomotion in adaptation (locomotion in adapt). Movement to the other chamber while the light signal was on was counted as avoidance, and movement to the other chamber on receiving the IS was counted as escape. The IS and light signal were terminated immediately after the rat moved to the other chamber. If the rat did not move to the other chamber, the behavior was counted as an error, and the rat received IS lasting 15s Movement through the gate after the cessation of the foot shock and prior to the next light signal was counted as an unnecessary cross.

(footshock = 0.8mA, max 15s) | Additionally, a warning signal light was provided 5 s prior to each IS. During a 5-min adaptation period before the task, the number of movements through the gate was counted as a cross in adaptation (cross in adapt), and movement within the chamber was counted as locomotion in adaptation (locomotion in adapt). Movement to the other chamber while the light signal was on was counted as avoidance, and movement to the other chamber on receiving the IS was counted as escape. The IS and light signal were terminated immediately after the rat moved to the other chamber. If the rat did not move to the other chamber, the behavior was counted as an error, and the rat received IS lasting 15s Movement through the gate after the cessation of the foot shock and prior to the next light signal was counted as an unnecessary cross.

column58: California Verbal Learning Test (CVLT) - CVLT, a list of 16 words (List A) is presented five times in succession, and subjects are instructed to recall as many of the words as possible after each presentation of the word list. After the five test trials of List A, a new list of words (List B) is read to the subjects, after which they are instructed to recall as many wordas possible from List B. Subjects are then asked to recall List A again (short delay free recall; SDFR) and, after a 20 minute interval, are asked to recall List A (long delay free recall; LDFR). Cued recall is also collected after the short and long delay free recall conditions and recognition memory is examined after the long-delay cued recall.
column61: dependent variables were the number of words recalled following Trial 1, performance on learning Trials 1 through 5 (total learning), after a short delay (short term retention) and after a longer delay (delayed recall), as well as short-delay and long-delay cued recall and a recognition test which yields the number of ‘hits’ (i.e., correctly identified target words). In addition subjects were evaluated for differences in proactive interference (List B minus List A Trial 1; difficulty in subsequent learning as a result of initial learning), retroactive interference (SDFR-List A Trial 5; difficulty recalling previously learned information as a result of newly learned information), retention (LDFR-SDFR; short term retention compared to long term retention) and response bias.

column58: California Verbal Learning Test (CVLT) - The California Verbal Learning Test is a multitrial serial learning test. A list of 16 words (list A) is presented five times in succession, and subjects are instructed to recall as many of the words as possible, in any order, after each presentation of the word list. After the five test trials of list A, a second list of words (list B), unrelated to the first list, is read to the subjects, who are instructed to recall as many words as possible from list B. The subjects are then asked to recall list A again (short delay) and, after a 20-mmute interval, are asked again to recall list A (long delay). The nesultant dependent variables are trial 1 performance (initial attentionand immediate memory), trial S performance (cumulative learning),list B performance (active interference from previous learning), words recalled following the short delay subtracted from list A trial 1 performance (retroactive interference), and long-delay recall (retention of information).
